item.title: In 2021, digitalization will be the driving force behind recruitment in Singapore
item.description: Randstad Singapore’s 2021 Market Outlook Report examines the economic and hiring trends anticipated for 2021. Jaya Dass, Managing Director for Randstad Malaysia and Singapore, emphasizes that digital transformation will be a key driver of talent demand in 2021. She predicts a surge in demand for tech professionals and digitally skilled individuals across various sectors. While acknowledging the cautious optimism of businesses in the wake of the pandemic, Dass highlights the need for agility and innovation to adapt to the evolving landscape.

item.title: The Swag employment superapp is designed to assist small and medium-sized enterprises as well as job seekers in Singapore and Malaysia
item.description: Employment Hero, a company specializing in HR, payroll, and employee engagement, is launching Swag, an employment superapp designed to modernize the employer-employee relationship. Building on its existing platform that streamlines HR and payroll processes for SMEs, Employment Hero is shifting its focus to enhance the job hunting experience for both employers and job seekers. Swag utilizes AI-powered recruitment tools to simplify and expedite the process of finding, onboarding, and rewarding talent.

item.title: Singaporean IT leaders are concerned that a shortage of skills could impede the progress of the Smart Nation initiative
item.description: 93% of Singaporean Chief Information Officers (CIOs) are worried that Singapore lacks the IT talent pool needed to successfully implement Smart Nation initiatives. Six out of 10 CIOs believe Smart Nation initiatives will lead to more IT jobs, and 53% believe these initiatives will boost average IT salaries. New independent research* commissioned by specialized recruiter Robert Half reveals that over 9 in 10 (93%) Singaporean IT leaders are concerned about the lack of readily available IT talent in Singapore to build a Smart Nation-ready workforce.

item.title: Robert Walters reports that there is still a high demand for talent in Singapore
item.description: Robert Walters, a recruitment firm, has published its Asia Job Index for the first quarter of 2015, highlighting that finding and hiring local talent remains a top concern in Singapore. The Asia Job Index monitors the number of job postings for professional roles across major job sites and national newspapers in China, Hong Kong, Japan, Malaysia, and Singapore. Toby Fowlston, Managing Director of Robert Walters Southeast Asia, noted that recruitment in Singapore is primarily driven by competition for a limited pool of candidates, making it challenging to attract the most qualified individuals for the right positions.

item.title: Zhaopin reveals changes in the entry-level job market in China
item.description: Zhaopin, a Chinese career platform that connects users with job opportunities, conducted a 2017 career survey of college graduates in China, revealing notable trends. The survey indicated that graduates faced a more challenging job market and lower average salaries, presenting a difficult situation for the 7.95 million graduates entering the workforce. 2017 Labor Market for College Graduates Difficult and very challenging: 40.8% Difficult, but acceptable: 47.0% The market was OK: 9.

item.title: Robert Walters believes that it is possible to both attract and retain tech talent
item.description: A recent survey by Robert Walters reveals that the tech talent shortage is significantly impacting businesses, with 70% of hiring managers requiring three months or more to fill tech positions. This shortage is hindering product development speed and highlighting the urgent need for effective talent acquisition strategies. The survey, conducted across Southeast Asia, emphasizes the difficulty of finding skilled tech professionals, despite recognizing its importance for business success. In response, Robert Walters has created a guidebook, “5 Lessons in Tackling the Tech Talent Shortage,” offering valuable insights from industry experts.

item.title: The 2015 Budget of Singapore provides support for businesses
item.description: Source: Ministry of Finance, Singapore. Infrastructure investments were also announced as part of Budget 2015. Singapore’s Budget 2015, presented by Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, included several business initiatives. These encompassed increased training assistance, a gradual reduction in business restructuring aid, a freeze on foreign worker levies (excluding manufacturing and construction), and measures to encourage innovation and expansion. Training and development Shanmugaratnam emphasized the government’s commitment to continuous investment in Singaporeans’ skills development.

item.title: Asia Pacific is dominated by formal severance policies, according to Right Management
item.description: Right Management, a global outplacement firm, found that companies in Asia Pacific, especially in Japan (94%) and China (92%), are more likely to have formal severance policies. According to their global report, “Severance Practices Around the World,” 75% of surveyed companies globally have formal, written severance policies, while 32% rely on informal, unwritten policies, or general practices. Source: Right Management. Click here to view the full infographic. Within Asia Pacific, 82% of companies reported having a formal policy, compared to around 70% in both the Americas and Europe.

item.title: Job Forward introduces the Startup Essence referral tool for startups and small to medium enterprises (SMEs)
item.description: Source: Job Forward. Job Forward, the first online social recruitment platform in Singapore, has introduced Startup Essence. This new addition to their referral-based platform helps startups and small to medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) by allowing them to build recruitment pages that attract and engage potential employees. The company aims to create a new avenue for these businesses to connect with individuals who are a good fit for their company culture.

item.title: Nearly two out of every three firms in the Asia Pacific region will provide outplacement services even when it is not mandated by law
item.description: Since the announcement of the large merger, rumors have been circulating. It’s clear that your department can’t absorb everyone from the other company, leading colleagues to compete for the boss’s attention, even though their own position is uncertain. Finally, HR schedules the meeting everyone has been anticipating. US-based HR consultant Nick Corcodilos, in a November 2013 edition of his “Ask the Headhunter” e-newsletter, states that outplacement is often offered as a consolation prize after termination.

item.title: Singaporeans will receive increased support for SkillsFuture
item.description: Source: SkillsFuture Singapore. Minister Puthucheary watches on as Ng (left) and Kevin Wo, Country GM, Microsoft Singapore (right) sign the MoU. To better equip Singapore’s workforce and businesses for a digital-centric economy, SkillsFuture Singapore (SSG) has launched new initiatives. These include a partnership with Microsoft and enhancements to the national SkillsFuture for Digital Workplace program. Dr. Janil Puthucheary, Singapore’s Senior Minister of State for the Ministry of Transport and Ministry of Communications and Information, announced these developments at the first SkillsFuture Festival X Smart Nation (SFFXSmart Nation) event.

item.title: Is your company using mobile for recruiting?
item.description: Mobile interaction is crucial for successful recruitment in India. In 2014-15, almost half of companies surveyed by TimesJobs reported receiving 10-20% of job applications via mobile phones, significantly up from the previous year. With mobile phones widespread, 65% of organizations in India now have mobile recruitment strategies, a 10% increase from the previous year, according to a TimesJobs.com survey. Jobseeker behavior has shifted dramatically, with 85% of online job searching now done on smartphones.

item.title: If you have digital or tech skills, chances are your salary is above average
item.description: Source: Willis Towers Watson. Report cover. The financial sector, particularly in digital roles, is experiencing salary stability due to a high demand for tech professionals. This trend persists despite overall economic weakness in other industries, including banking, according to the global advisory firm Willis Towers Watson. Businesses across all sectors are becoming progressively reliant on data and technology, and the banking industry is no exception. This shift has resulted in a talent competition where technological expertise is more valuable than financial background.

item.title: Discover your leadership potential with a revolutionary tool from Hogan Assessment Systems and Sirota
item.description: On July 30th at the Oasia Hotel Singapore, Dr. Tomas Chamorro-Premuzic, CEO of Hogan Assessment Systems, a leader in personality profiling and psychometric testing, along with Lewis Garrad, Managing Director Asia Pacific at Sirota, a performance consulting firm, will preview a new employee assessment model they jointly developed. Launching in the Asia Pacific market in October 2015, the Engaging Leader tool will help companies and brands better identify and develop leadership potential.

item.title: Glassdoor has released a list of the top 10 workplaces in Singapore
item.description: The job and recruiting website Glassdoor has revealed the winners of its annual Employees’ Choice Awards, which included a category for Singapore for the first time. These awards recognize the Best Places to Work in 2020 across nine countries, including Singapore. The rankings are determined by the input of employees who anonymously share their experiences through company reviews on Glassdoor. This feedback encompasses their job, work environment, and employer over the past year.

item.title: Avoid using the following words on your resume: CareerBuilder
item.description: A CareerBuilder survey found that almost 70% of hiring managers spend less than two minutes looking at resumes, meaning word choice is critical for job seekers. Rosemary Haefner, CareerBuilder’s VP of human resources, advises using strong action verbs that highlight specific experiences, skills, and achievements. She cautions against subjective terms and clichés because they fail to convey concrete information. For example, instead of claiming to be “results-driven,” demonstrate actual results.

item.title: CA Technologies has implemented a new global parental leave policy
item.description: CA Technologies is implementing a new parental leave policy to support changing family dynamics and promote work-life balance and gender diversity. The company will now offer a minimum of 12 weeks paid leave during the first year after the birth or adoption of a child to all employees globally. This benefit provides financial support and flexibility for parents to care for their child during the first year. Melinda Walsh, VP of People Business Partner for Asia Pacific and Japan at CA Technologies, stated this new policy demonstrates the company’s commitment to employee well-being and enhances their existing family-friendly benefits.

item.title: Flightleaders.com will enhance its programs in 2018
item.description: Source: Flightleaders.com website. An aircraft cockpit. Flightleaders.com, an aviation-inspired leadership training provider and part of the McGallen & Bolden Group, intends to expand its program offerings throughout 2018. Dr. Seamus Phan, a Leadership Trainer with Flightleaders.com specializing in corporate leadership and philosophical approaches, believes corporate training will be highly sought after due to generational gaps in the workplace. He argues this need goes beyond technological advancements and other disruptive trends, as managing people and leadership will remain critical challenges.

item.title: Zhaopin in China introduces chat feature to Highpin recruitment platform
item.description: Source: Highpin.cn website. Zhaopin, a Chinese career platform, has introduced Highpin Chat, a desktop-based instant messaging feature for its executive recruitment site, Highpin.cn. This new chat feature aims to streamline the hiring process on Highpin.cn. Recruiters and employers can now directly connect with candidates, enabling better candidate evaluation and efficient job matching. Similarly, job seekers can use the chat to ask recruiters and employers about specific roles and follow their application status in real time.

item.title: Employers in Singapore are struggling with stress and mental health concerns
item.description: A large majority (72%) of Singaporean employers view stress and mental health as factors that negatively impact productivity, according to the APAC Benefits Strategy Study 2017 conducted by global professional services firm Aon. The International Labour Organization has labeled stress a “global epidemic” and “silent killer,” particularly within many Asian countries experiencing rapid economic growth and adopting Western lifestyles, including Singapore, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and mainland China. Early physical symptoms of stress can manifest as chronic back pain, fatigue, and headaches.

item.title: Workers are open to making concessions in return for flexible schedules and locations
item.description: According to the ADP Research Institute’s People at Work 2022: A Global Workforce View report, employees desire flexible work arrangements and are willing to negotiate to achieve them. The global survey of nearly 33,000 individuals across 17 countries indicates that half of the respondents would accept lower pay for schedule flexibility, even without altering total work hours. In Singapore, over 72% desire schedule flexibility with consistent hours, while 38% would consider a pay reduction for location flexibility.

item.title: Finding good people is still a challenge, according to ManpowerGroup
item.description: Source: ManpowerGroup infographic. Around the world, the most difficult positions to fill are in skilled trades (particularly chefs, bakers, butchers, mechanics, and electricians), sales, engineering (mechanical, electrical, and civil), technician roles, and drivers (especially heavy vehicle operators), according to workforce experts ManpowerGroup. The situation in Singapore is somewhat different. While engineers are among the top five hardest roles to fill, as elsewhere, the other four are accounting and finance professionals, sales representatives, secretaries (including receptionists and administrative assistants), and marketing, public relations, and communications specialists.

item.title: TAKAUD will be hosting its first-ever Middle East Pensions Conference
item.description: Source: _Middle East Pensions Conference _website. With the support of the Central Bank of Bahrain, TAKAUD, a leading provider of savings, investment, and pension solutions in the MENA region, is gathering government officials and financial service leaders to discuss the development of robust pension plans for citizens and foreign workers across the region. The first-ever Middle East Pensions Conference will occur in Bahrain on October 18, 2016. The conference aims to raise awareness and encourage action towards bringing Middle Eastern pension standards in line with developed countries.

item.title: The practice of recruiting and retaining skilled individuals
item.description: Innovative talent acquisition strategies are helping some companies secure the best possible candidates. Mei-lynn Chan, Head of Organizational Development, Group Human Capital at Maybank, emphasizes the need for HR departments to approach hiring from a business perspective. This involves quantifying HR activities into tangible business metrics. She argues that while budget constraints may have traditionally limited HR’s hiring choices, a new perspective allows for hiring the right talent if the business can absorb the cost until the hire generates a return on investment.

item.title: Financial services companies are placing a greater emphasis on developing a strong risk culture
item.description: A recent study by Mercer focusing on executive compensation in the global financial services industry found that a majority of firms are prioritizing the development of robust risk cultures within their organizations. Sixty-two percent of surveyed firms reported significant efforts to penalize misconduct and non-compliance, while 60% demonstrated clear leadership commitment to ethical behavior. Furthermore, 58% have established and communicated unambiguous objectives related to risk culture. Vicki Elliott, Senior Partner and Financial Services Talent Leader at Mercer, highlighted the importance of senior leaders setting a positive example when it comes to risk management and compliance.

item.title: Dubai Islamic Bank has been included in LinkedIn's Most In-Demand Employers 2015 list for the MENA region
item.description: Source: DIB. Dubai Islamic Bank (DIB), the leading Islamic bank in the UAE, has been acknowledged by LinkedIn as one of the most desirable employers in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region. DIB secured the 16th position on LinkedIn’s “Most In-Demand Employers” 2015 list for the MENA region, placing it among the top 10 local brands and making it the only bank to achieve this distinction. LinkedIn annually publishes a list of top employers globally based on extensive data gathered from billions of member interactions.

item.title: Xero creates cloud-based accounting software specifically tailored for business owners
item.description: Fitzgerald. Despite the significant benefits, small and mid-sized businesses (SMBs) are slow to embrace cloud computing. Kevin Fitzgerald, FCCA, Regional Director for Asia at cloud accounting software provider Xero, noted that cloud adoption remains a hurdle, particularly in accounting. Speaking at the recent Accounting & Finance Show Asia 2018 in Singapore, Fitzgerald shared that Xero’s potential clients often express concerns about security and privacy. He pointed out the irony, stating, “They don’t realize they are already in the cloud if they use a banking app or an email server.

item.title: The skills you possess will be valuable in securing future employment opportunities
item.description: Legrand illustrates how LinkedIn is innovating by connecting existing skills with the needs of emerging jobs. Olivier Legrand, Managing Director for Asia Pacific at LinkedIn, suggests that many individuals already possess some qualifications for in-demand jobs without realizing it. During his keynote, “Job titles are out, skill sets are in,” at the Singapore Computer Society’s Tech3 Forum, Legrand stated that LinkedIn aims to connect its members not only with employers but also with suitable companies, relevant jobs, and essential skills for future career prospects.

item.title: Digital recruitment is becoming increasingly popular, with HireVue leading the way
item.description: HireVue, a leading digital recruiting platform, facilitates thousands of interviews daily. The company’s CEO, Mark Newman, highlights the global employment paradox: millions of professionals are unemployed while companies struggle to fill open positions. HireVue aims to bridge this gap by streamlining the hiring process and creating a level playing field for all candidates, regardless of background. The company emphasizes the importance of allowing candidates to showcase their skills and connect with potential employers effectively.

item.title: Southeast Asia's unique focus on talent management sets it apart as a hub for talented individuals in the region
item.description: PageUp People, a global talent management solutions company, has introduced “Talented Southeast Asia,” a publication dedicated to talent management in Southeast Asia. The book tackles significant challenges and future trends for employers, drawing from insights gathered from over 100 interviews with business and HR leaders over a year. Sylvia Vorhauser-Smith, PageUp People’s Senior Vice President of Global Research and co-author, highlights the region’s distinct characteristics and the varying approaches to talent management.

item.title: Workers value recognition more than money
item.description: Source: ACCA report. Tone at the top influences corporate behaviour the most, according to 61% of respondents. A recent report by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) titled “Culture and channelling corporate behaviour: ACCA member survey” found that workplace recognition is the most significant motivator for employees across all ages, industries, and locations. Notably, this recognition even outweighs monetary rewards. The survey, conducted with support from the Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC), gathered insights from nearly 2,000 ACCA finance professionals globally.

item.title: Corporate India is facing challenges in recruiting women candidates for job positions
item.description: MyParichay, a Facebook-based recruiting platform, states that social recruiting is no longer optional. They report that 90% of recruiters believe a social media-based hiring tool would offer a competitive edge in hiring a gender-diverse workforce. Source: MyParichay A company-wide survey in India conducted by MyParichay revealed that 85% of companies surveyed believe diversity is critical for workplace innovation. However, MyParichay found that 75% of recruiters struggle to find qualified female candidates to meet the gender diversity goals set by leadership.

item.title: John Tschohl highlights 10 errors in corporate training
item.description: John Tschohl, President of the Service Quality Institute, argues that a significant amount of time and money invested in training is often unproductive. He emphasizes that ineffective training leads to wasted resources, particularly considering labor time as a major expense. Tschohl, a seasoned trainer and author, identifies ten common pitfalls in training programs: Excessive Group Sizes: Productive discussions are hampered by large groups. Limiting sessions to around 15 participants fosters engagement and skill development.

item.title: Singapore is known for having one of the most competitive talent markets in Asia
item.description: Source: Randstad Sourceright website. Global figures. Randstad Sourceright, a global staffing agency, has released its 2016 Talent Trends Report, a guide highlighting 30 significant trends influencing talent, employees, and businesses this year. The report incorporates insights from almost 400 HR, talent, and business leaders representing over 60 countries. Randstad Sourceright identified the lack of essential skills and its subsequent impact on businesses, leadership, and succession planning as the most significant talent management challenge today.

item.title: "Robert Walters focuses on hiring for long-term success based on potential."
item.description: In Southeast Asia, while a remarkable 94% of individuals hired for potential stay in their roles, nearly half of hiring managers remain hesitant to move away from experience-based recruitment. This resistance persists despite the significant resources wasted on unsuitable candidates. This data comes from “Grow your Talent, Hire Based on Potential,” a guide published by Robert Walters in October 2019, which explores the benefits of hiring for potential as a sustainable talent strategy.

item.title: The demand for jobs in Singapore is being driven by digitization, according to Robert Walters
item.description: Source: Robert Walters. Click on the image to view a larger version. According to the international recruitment firm Robert Walters, the increasing presence of digital technology was the main driver of recruitment in Singapore during the second quarter of 2015. These insights were published in the company’s Asia Job Index for Q2 2015. Toby Fowlston, Managing Director of Robert Walters Southeast Asia, acknowledged the anticipated decrease in job advertisements during this quarter.

item.title: DBS launches improved paternity leave program in Singapore
item.description: DBS Bank will enhance its paternity leave policy in Singapore, following Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong’s call to extend such leave during the National Day Rally on August 23. This new policy, announced on August 26, allows fathers employed by the bank to take two weeks of paternity leave, retroactive to January 2015. Cheong Meng Foong, DBS Group Head of Rewards, emphasized the bank’s commitment to its employees’ well-being: “At DBS, people are our most important resource, and we consistently seek to support them.

item.title: SEEK's Jobstreet introduces a new employment platform powered by artificial intelligence
item.description: Jobstreet by SEEK, a leading career and talent platform, has launched a new and improved employment platform powered by SEEK’s AI technology. This upgrade aims to create a better experience for both job seekers and employers by improving job matches and providing more in-depth insights. This initiative is a component of SEEK’s ongoing efforts to unify its online employment platforms across the Asia Pacific region, including SEEK in Australia and New Zealand, Jobstreet in Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Indonesia, and JobsDB in Hong Kong and Thailand.

item.title: Strong job market in Hong Kong for 2015
item.description: A new report by recruitment firm REED indicates that 78% of employees in Hong Kong received a pay raise in the last year. The report, titled REED 2015 Salary Survey and Market Insight, covers 14 countries across Asia, Australia, Europe, and the Middle East. REED predicts that Hong Kong’s thriving job market will continue to grow in 2015, driven by substantial foreign investments. The financial, digital marketing, e-commerce, and sales & marketing industries are expected to be particularly strong.

item.title: 80% of Singaporeans living abroad are interested in returning to work in their home country
item.description: A new report from Robert Walters, a professional recruitment firm, suggests that competition for skilled workers in Singapore will increase in 2016. This demand will likely lead to more attempts to recruit Singaporeans working abroad. Hiring managers believe that these experienced professionals could help alleviate the tight labor market, benefiting both companies and the “Fair Consideration Framework,” which promotes local hiring. Returning Singaporeans are desirable candidates because they often have international experience and a broader range of skills compared to their counterparts who haven’t worked overseas.

item.title: Employees in Singapore are seeking opportunities for career advancement and a positive work environment
item.description: Source: CareerBuilder Singapore. The attributes of an Employer of Choice. A 2017 survey by CareerBuilder Singapore reveals that simply offering a competitive salary isn’t enough to attract and keep talented employees. The study, titled Employer of Choice Survey* 2017, showed that Singaporean workers prioritize strong career growth prospects and an inclusive work environment over financial compensation when selecting an ideal employer. Source: CareerBuilder Singapore. What an ideal job looks like.

item.title: Salary growth is expected in Southeast Asia as there is a high demand for IT skillsets in key sectors
item.description: Singapore’s IT sector is expected to experience high demand for skilled professionals and contract workers in 2018, particularly in fintech, healthcare, and technology. Specialized skills will be highly sought after in 2018 across accounting and finance, human resources, sales and marketing, and technology sectors. According to the 2018 Salary Survey by Robert Walters, a professional recruitment firm, the economic outlook for the coming year is positive. The survey anticipates that continued digitalization and market expansion in Southeast Asia will fuel salary growth.

item.title: Robert Half suggests diversifying incentives in order to retain talent
item.description: A significant portion of Singapore’s workforce prioritizes work-life balance over higher salaries, according to a recent study. The Robert Half 2017 Salary Guide highlights that 69% of Singaporean employees are driven by more than just monetary compensation. The study reveals that nearly half (43%) would accept lower pay for flexible work hours, while over a third (37%) would choose the ability to work remotely over a pay raise. Non-financial benefits are highly valued by Singaporean workers, with 28% willing to trade a portion of their salary for increased medical benefits and 20% favoring more vacation time.

item.title: Contract positions are the perfect solution for companies in Singapore
item.description: A recent survey by Robert Walters, a global recruitment firm, indicates a rise in contract employment in Singapore. The Singapore Contracting Survey reveals that hiring managers are increasingly turning to skilled contract workers due to difficulties in obtaining approval for permanent positions. Many companies are implementing hiring freezes, often mandated by their headquarters, leading managers in Singapore to seek adaptable, temporary staffing solutions. The survey, which polled over 300 professionals in Singapore with contracting experience, explored the advantages and disadvantages of contract work.

item.title: Top-paying technology jobs for 2014 - for those in the United States
item.description: The 2014 Salary Guides published by Robert Half Technology and The Creative Group identify six technology and digital jobs experiencing high demand in the US. This demand may also be reflected in the Asia Pacific region. Companies are specifically seeking professionals skilled in information and network security, data analysis for business intelligence, and mobile development. “Building a strong online presence and engaging customers through mobile platforms is crucial for businesses today,” says John Reed, Senior Executive Director of Robert Half Technology and The Creative Group.

item.title: The demand for HR and admin professionals is increasing in Malaysia
item.description: For the first time since March 2018, HR and administrative (admin) jobs in Malaysia experienced a 2% year-over-year increase in December. This job category also saw recent positive short-term growth, with a 4% rise month-over-month and a 2% increase over three months. The Philippines echoed this positive trend, with online hiring demand for HR and admin professionals surging by 22% year-on-year. Demand for HR and admin interns remained strong in Malaysia and the Philippines, representing the highest demand among all surveyed occupations at 13% and 5%, respectively.

item.title: DBS introduces an integrated health management portal to assist employees in maintaining their well-being
item.description: Source: DBS. To introduce iHealth@DBS, DBS Asia Hub employees were encouraged to participate in a large group workout. DBS Bank introduced iHealth@DBS, a comprehensive health management platform, to further cultivate a culture of well-being for its employees. The goal of this centralized platform is to promote lasting behavioral changes among staff. This will be achieved through interactive engagement on digital platforms, including mobile devices and wearable technology. iHealth@DBS is the newest addition to a comprehensive package of wellness benefits offered to DBS employees.

item.title: Foo See Yang has been appointed as the Vice President and Country General Manager for Singapore at Kelly Services
item.description: Source: Kelly Services. Foo. Kelly Services appointed Foo See Yang to the position of Vice President and Country General Manager for Singapore, starting January 1st of this year. With over 15 years in the recruitment field, Foo will manage over 150 consultants for the global staffing and recruitment company in Singapore. “See Yang has been with Kelly Services for over 13 years. As a Singaporean with deep knowledge of this market, he has provided valuable local perspectives on Singapore’s dynamic talent landscape and has proven himself to be a successful and respected leader,” stated Natalia Shuman, Senior Vice President and General Manager for Kelly Services, EMEA and APAC regions.

item.title: Helping individuals with disabilities transition from training programs to meaningful employment opportunities
item.description: Individuals with disabilities should be placed in jobs where they can acquire skills on the job, rather than receiving training without a clear path to employment. Christy Lynch, CEO of KARE Ireland, an organization supporting individuals with intellectual disabilities and their families, emphasized the importance of collaborating with both individuals with disabilities and employers to create truly empowering opportunities. He spoke at the “Towards an Inclusive Workforce 2015” event, co-organized by SPD and supported by SG Enable and the Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA).

item.title: Job seekers in Singapore are turning to AI to help ease the difficulties of finding a job
item.description: A recent Indeed survey of 2,000 Singaporeans found that the biggest hurdles for job seekers are cumbersome recruitment processes, a lack of personalization, and unfair hiring practices. Interestingly, over half of those surveyed believe AI could make job hunting more efficient and effective, potentially improving employment prospects for many. Conducted in December 2017, the research highlighted job seekers’ frustrations with time-consuming and irrelevant application processes. 55% found these processes weren’t tailored to their skills and experience.

item.title: TalentBin by Monster searches through social networks to find potential candidates for recruitment
item.description: Source: Monster website. Monster recently launched its TalentBin platform across multiple regions to help businesses locate and engage skilled professionals. Functioning as a specialized search engine for talent, the software grants recruiters access to a pool of potential candidates who might not be easily discoverable through traditional methods. This is achieved by analyzing and leveraging professional information individuals share on various social media platforms. TalentBin not only automates and simplifies the process of identifying potential candidates through site monitoring, data interpretation, and profile matching but also makes hiring more efficient, allowing recruiters to achieve more in less time.

item.title: Recruitment services supported by artificial intelligence offer a more precise matching process
item.description: AnyMind Group, a company focused on using AI to change industries, has introduced TalentMind, a new business unit featuring AI-powered recruitment software. TalentMind offers a comprehensive platform using natural language processing (NLP), profile analysis, and machine learning to screen, analyze, and match potential candidates with businesses. The platform will launch in four stages: ● TalentMind screening - This stage analyzes social media and resume data to assess a candidate’s cultural fit and personality based on their profile.

item.title: DBS has been honored with the NTUC Women's Development Secretariat SG50 Special Award
item.description: DBS Bank has been granted the NTUC Women’s Development Secretariat (WDS) SG50 Special Award as recognition for its committed flexible working program and employee support systems. These programs are designed to assist staff in improving their time management and balancing their work and personal responsibilities. Cheong Meng Foong, Managing Director of Group Human Resources – Reward, stated that DBS takes a comprehensive approach to create a workplace where employees feel empowered, connected, and valued.

item.title: The IBM Kenexa Talent Suite leverages big data to benefit HR
item.description: IBM has introduced a new software-as-a-service (SaaS) product designed to provide Chief Human Resources Officers (CHROs) and other executives with valuable insights from employee data. The cloud-based IBM Kenexa Talent Suite helps organizations enhance the efficiency and accuracy of their hiring processes, boost workforce productivity, and foster employee connections in ways that positively influence business outcomes. This software empowers HR teams to analyze extensive employee data, encompassing work history, social interactions, skills development, and individual interests.

item.title: Aon Hewitt provides insights on Malaysia's perspective in the Total Compensation Measurement study
item.description: Aon Hewitt, a global human resource consulting firm, has published their Total Compensation Measurement (TCM) 2015 Study. This comprehensive report analyzes compensation data from 25,000 positions in 180 countries. Salary increase by industry sector in Malaysia While the global GDP is projected to grow from 3.1% in 2015 to 3.6% in 2016, regional economic conditions play a vital role in employee compensation decisions. In Southeast Asia, the Philippines and Vietnam led in 2015 with 6% and 6.

item.title: There is a lack of interest among Singapore job seekers in pursuing opportunities in emerging technology roles
item.description: A recent study of tech job postings on Indeed found a shortage of job seekers in Singapore pursuing careers in technology. To understand the extent of the problem, researchers compared job postings to job searches and overall interest in four areas: cybersecurity, data science, machine learning, and robotics over a two-year period. Indeed’s research highlighted a significant gap between available cybersecurity jobs and individuals seeking them. The surge in demand for cybersecurity professionals stems from recent high-profile cybersecurity incidents in Singapore and the government’s emphasis on cybersecurity.

item.title: Excelity Global will be providing HR and payroll services in Indonesia through Cekindo Bisnis
item.description: Excelity Global Solutions, the largest payroll service provider in Asia, has partnered with Cekindo Bisnis Grup to offer its services in Indonesia. Excelity Global, which operates in 19 countries across Asia Pacific, provides payroll outsourcing and human capital management cloud services. Indonesia, with a large SME market, presents a significant opportunity for Excelity. SMEs make up over 98% of companies in Indonesia and contribute significantly to the country’s GDP. By collaborating with Cekindo, a provider of market-entry and corporate secretarial services, Excelity aims to simplify HR and payroll processes for businesses in Indonesia.

item.title: The Hong Kong budget prioritizes innovation to capitalize on opportunities in a changing economic landscape
item.description: In his 2016-17 Budget address, Hong Kong Financial Secretary John Tsang emphasized the need for the city to adapt to a changing global economy driven by technology and the rise of emerging markets. He highlighted robotics, healthy aging, and smart city initiatives as potential areas for Hong Kong to leverage its strengths. Tsang announced plans to promote smart production and research in the Tseung Kwan O Industrial Estate, utilizing robotics and IT to advance the entire value chain, from research and development to marketing.

item.title: According to LinkedIn, 65% of employees in Singapore are planning to change jobs in 2023
item.description: Although hiring in Singapore experienced a significant drop of 34% in December 2022 compared to the previous year, and despite economic uncertainties, professionals are adopting a forward-thinking approach to their careers. They are investing in skill development and actively pursuing opportunities for advancement. LinkedIn’s research indicates that a considerable 65% of professionals are contemplating job changes in 2023. The desire for enhanced financial stability amidst rising living costs is a primary driver behind this job search trend.

item.title: Hilton ranks among the top three employers in the hospitality industry in Greater China
item.description: Source: Hilton. Hilton earned the title of Best Hospitality Company to Work For in Greater China. For the second year in a row, Hilton has secured a spot among the top three companies to work for in Greater China, according to the global research and consulting firm Great Place To Work Institute. Holding the highest position among hospitality companies on the 2016 list, Hilton also received recognition from 51job Inc.

item.title: Singapore companies are considering hiring senior technology professionals to address the shortage of talent
item.description: Despite job market growth, a 2017 survey by the Singapore Infocomm Technology Federation (SiTF) reveals that the infocommunications (ICM) industry struggles to find talent with the right IT and business skills. The survey of 181 companies found that 75% consider recruiting suitable talent their biggest challenge. This problem particularly affects startups (91%), followed by small and medium enterprises (SMEs) at 76% and multinational corporations (MNCs) at 75%. Source: SITF. item.title: Companies are focusing on ensuring that their workforces are prepared for the future
item.description: - The Asia-Pacific region is seeing a high demand for professionals with a mix of skills, especially those with expertise in technology and the ability to adapt to new situations. This trend is driven by the increasing adoption of digital technologies across various sectors. - To attract and keep skilled workers, companies are refining their hiring strategies to identify individuals who are not only experts in their fields but also adaptable and possess a global perspective.

item.title: Various approaches to talent management in Asia
item.description: Source: ECN. Attracting and retaining skilled managers in Asia has become increasingly crucial for business leaders. A recent survey by the Economist Corporate Network (ECN) of 550 member companies in Asia revealed that 95% of CEOs actively engage in talent management practices. However, their level and type of involvement differ significantly. The report, Aligned for Success? Strategy, talent management and the role of the CEO in Asia, indicates that CEOs primarily focus on the strategic aspects of human capital, such as forecasting future workforce needs and organizational design.

item.title: Solarwinds is advocating for the recognition of IT personnel on September 15th as IT Professionals Day
item.description: SolarWinds, a company that provides software for managing hybrid IT infrastructures, has declared the third Tuesday of September (starting on September 15, 2015) as IT Professionals Day. This day is meant to show appreciation for IT professionals, recognizing their often-unsung contributions to modern businesses. To mark IT Professionals Day, SolarWinds published the findings of their IT Pro Value Survey. This research highlights the significant contributions of Singaporean IT professionals. It examines how much end-users value IT departments and explores how valued IT professionals feel within their organizations.

item.title: A white paper providing solutions for talent management in the Chinese hospitality industry
item.description: Florida International University’s Chaplin School of Hospitality & Tourism Management (CSHTM) and its Institute for Hospitality & Tourism Education & Research (IHTER) have published a new resource for HR professionals and hospitality businesses, particularly those working with Chinese markets. The white paper, titled “Managing Growing Pains of China’s Relentless Hotel Development Pipeline,” examines the significant lack of qualified talent within China’s rapidly expanding hotel industry. The paper offers practical solutions such as professional development programs, conflict resolution strategies, and clearly defined career paths to attract and retain skilled employees.

item.title: The CIER Employment Index indicates a decrease in employment rates in China
item.description: The Chinese job platform Zhaopin and the China Institute for Employment Research (CIER) at Renmin University have published their CIER Employment Index Report for July to September 2015.
